description: A provider uploads a claim PDF for a knee arthroscopy performed on a Saturday and asks whether the weekend service impacts reimbursement. The assistant extracts claim data, looks up the CPT code, queries the insurer's policy for weekend differentials, and explains the reimbursement implications.

messages.content: You are MedClaim AI Analyzer, an assistant that extracts health‑claim data from PDFs, validates CPT/HCPCS/ICD‑10 codes against insurer policies, flags billing errors, and generates correction suggestions. Use the provided tools to gather information and answer the provider's questions clearly.

I just submitted a claim for a knee arthroscopy (CPT 29881) performed on Saturday, March 9, 2024 for patient John Doe under my AETNA plan ABC123. Will the weekend affect reimbursement? I have attached the claim PDF.
Let me extract the text from the PDF and parse the claim details.

Patient Name: John Doe
Date of Service: 03/09/2024 (Saturday)
Provider: Dr. Emily Smith
CPT Code: 29881
Diagnosis: M17.11 (Unilateral primary osteoarthritis, right knee)
Charges: $1,400
Insurer: AETNA
Policy ID: ABC123
Now I will convert the raw text into a structured claim object.

messages.content: I will look up the CPT code 29881 to get its description and any required modifiers.
Next, I will query AETNA policy ABC123 for coverage details on CPT 29881, including any weekend service differentials.

Here’s what I found:

- **CPT 29881** (knee arthroscopy) is covered under your AETNA plan ABC123.
- The standard maximum reimbursement for this procedure is **$1,500**.
- Your claim lists a charge of **$1,400**, which is within the allowed amount.
- AETNA’s policy applies a **10% weekend surcharge** for services performed on Saturday or Sunday. This surcharge is **added to the reimbursable amount**, not deducted.

Because the surcharge is a credit to the provider, it actually **increases** the amount you can be paid. The claim you submitted will be processed at the standard rate of $1,400, and the weekend surcharge will be applied on top, resulting in an additional $140 (10% of $1,400) that the insurer should reimburse.

**Bottom line:** The weekend does **not** reduce your reimbursement; it adds a small extra payment. Your claim should be approved without any denial related to the service day.

If you need a formal summary to attach to the claim or have any other claims to review, just let me know!
